Unità di Soccorso Giapponesi (Japanese Rescue Teams) is a cooperative game portraying the aim of the Japanese Rescue Teams to save and protect the Japanese population from the dangers which can occur in the Japanese cities, like earthquakes, typhoons, tsunamis and nuclear pollution. This game is in memory of all the people died during the March 2011 Japanese earthquake and tsunami.
Each player represent a Japanese Rescue Team and will try to solve the problems ariring in the Japaed on the map.

The objective of the players is to reach the level 8 of the Level of Saved Lifes Track (LSL) depicted on the map, which means having saved most of the affected population and thus avoiding to reach the level -7, which would mean the loss of too many lives.
Each player chooses its set of Japanese Rescue Teams (JRT) and deploy the Team 1 in a city on the map. All the Problem Tiles are put in a cup and shuffled together.
The Sequence of play is like the following:
The playing player rolls the d12 die: if the result is 1-6 a new Problem arises (go to c); if the result is 7-12, no new Problems! (go to e.)
c. Roll the d12 die to see in which city the Problem occur (each city has a name and a reference number)
d. Take one Problem Tile form the cup, see which kind of problem is shown and put it near the city rolled during c.
e. Every Player can move his/her JRT in any city shown in the map, normally where there is a Problem or Ruins; there he/she tries to solve a Problem, starting from the playing Player.
A JRT can try to solve one Problem per turn, so if there is more than one Problem Tile in a city, the playing Player must choose which one will be tried by his/her JRT.
If the JRT manages to resolve the Problem, raise by 1 level the LSL Track, turn the Problem tile on the Ruins side.
If the JRT does not manage to solve the Problem, the Problem remains and at the start of the next turn, will decrease the LSL:
The players have to clear Ruins in order to avoid negative DRM in solving the Problems.

A nice small cooperative game!

147827.description: Council of Verona: Poison Expansion adds two new tokens per player into the base game; poison tokens and antidote tokens. Influence Cards that end the game with more poison than antidote tokens on them are physically removed from the play area which may affect scoring agendas.
147827.name: Council of Verona: Poison Expansion

147829.name: Norsgard
147829.description:
Norsgard; is a tabletop wargame set in the cold realm of Isbran - a land of ice and fire. The players in this game play out the skirmishes of small bands of warriors led into battle by heroes.
"During the game the situation changes rapidly - until you have secured your victory, you can never be sure of it. React to your opponents actions, block their charges, and keep them from blocking yours at the crucial moment. Play Special Cards to turn the tide of battle to give yourself the advantage and when combat commences, choose the right Tactic and push your enemies onto the defensive. From turn to turn build your dominance and win combats so that the initiative stays with you. Press your opponent until you reach your goals. Together, create an epic battle in which every warrior plays their part!


"Never again will you have to depend on a single dice roll - in this game you literally roll a handful. Watch as they shape the fate of your warriors and thanks to simple, easy-to-learn mechanics you will be able to concentrate on your strategy instead of trying to remember an obscure rules technicality.
"Create your own saga, direct your heroes, and influence their future. In many cases the players will decide the fate of their characters; in big tournaments and during fierce battles they may acquire legendary artifacts or gain experience - become a great leader, a fearsome warrior - or they may perish... Norsgard awaits it's heroes, and always remember:
Fortune favours the bold!

147830.name: 1862: Glendale (American Civil War in 3D)
147830.description:
Glendale is the sixteenth battle in the series and is the sixth in our Peninsula Campaign set of 1862. The Confederates are in a position to attack the Union army who is retreating towards Harrison's Landing on the James River. Combat is designed around the three factors that appear on the unit counters, these indicate the Range, Attack and Strength of the represented unit. You don’t even need any dice to play the game since a dice tile system is included with the game, but if you want to roll dice then it’s the simple six sided variety that you will require.

The game board is designed to be used either 2 dimensionally as a straight print and play or 3 dimensionally, this takes a little more time to construct but it is well worth the effort for the impressive game board you get at its completion. The final 3D game board gives a realistic feel to the terrain and shows the tactical dispositions of all the game counters.

147831.description:
In this board game of ancient colonization for 2-5 players, pilot your ship of colonists to an unknown Mediterranean shore and establish colonies in fortuitous locations. Establish a colony as soon as possible or pursue the ideal location. Establish close to others to enhance trade, or remain safe and remote. Re-invest to grow your colonies or pursue those of others. Send your ship home or use it in the new waters. Create more colonies or thrive safely behind strong walls. Negotiate the path between speedy growth and the disruption it causes.

A war game of building up a civilization including a modular board, variable powers and a rich set of heavily-researched cards providing special powers.
147831.name: Poleis

147832.name: Martial Masters
147832.description:
User Summary

A fighting arcade game for one or two players. Has 12 character, each character has a large number of attacks and special moves, the game has a combo system, moves can be canceled in mid animation, a shadow move that creates a shadow double of your character that will fight by itself, and a super meter that can be used to do special attacks or to knock opponents away from you.

147833.name: Wade Hixton's Counter Punch
videogameversion: North American Game Boy Advance edition
147833.description:
User Summary

A boxing game similar in style to Super Punch Out on the SNES. The game features a story mode and eight boxers to defeat.

147834.description:
From the publisher's web site:

"This is a download of 53 mp3 recordings of the Mice and Mystics: Sorrow and Remembrance Story Moments. Named and categorized for ease of use, these are intended to be played at the appropriate moments during the chapters of that story book.

"The entire sale price of this item will be donated to the Jack Vasel Memorial Fund."

In Mice and Mystics, each scenario is preceded by story elements that are read to the players to set the mood and outline the objectives. These mp3 files are a reading of these story elements by a professional voice actor intended to enhance play experience and to help immerse the players in the story.
147834.name: Mice and Mystics: Story Moments MP3s

147835.name: NAtURAL DOCtRINE
147835.description:
The game will be a fantasy simulation-type RPG based along the concept of natural selection. The setting is within a universe where humans fight other races with magic and swords.

Source: Wikipedia, "Natural Doctrine", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

147837.name: Irritum
147837.description:
Irritum is a 3d platformer game with puzzle elements. The game revolves around the player trying to escape from limbo after attempting suicide. Use the unique plane-changing feature to escape purgatory and return to the life you once held.

Source: The Game Website.

147838.name: Dishonored - Dunwall City Trials
147838.description:
User Summary

The game adds 10 challenge maps in which the player must defeat waves of enemies, complete time-trial challenges, and perform a series of drop assassinations in which the player kills a target by dropping from a location above the target.

147840.name: Dishonored - The Knife of Dunwall
videogamehonor: 2013 Spike (VGX) Best DLC of the Year Nominee
147840.description:
User Summary

The Knife of Dunwall follows the assassin Daud as he seeks redemption for murdering Empress Jessamine in Dishonored's main story.

Daud has his own abilities including: "Void Gaze", which combines the functions of Corvo's "Dark Vision" with those of The Heart, guiding Daud to runes and bone charms; "Chokedust", which dazes enemies; and an ability which allows Daud to summon his assassin followers. Additionally Daud also has his own gadgets such as stun mines, a concealed wrist-mounted bow, and arc mines that disintegrate enemies. The Knife of Dunwall's plot runs parallel to that of Dishonored's, providing Daud's perspective on events, and introduces new locations such as a whale slaughterhouse and Dunwall's affluent legal district. The Knife of Dunwall also features an additional difficulty level, "Master Assassin", which is made available after completing the content.

147841.name: Dishonored - The Brigmore Witches
147841.description:
User Summary

The Brigmore Witches follows the assassin Daud as he seeks redemption for murdering Empress Jessamine in Dishonored's main story.

The Brigmore Witches follows Daud's quest to stop the eponymous witches from enacting a powerful ritual that will doom him, and concludes with Daud's ultimate fate at the hands of Corvo in the core game. The DLC carries over player choices and upgrades from a The Knife of Dunwall saved game.

147842.name: Dishonored - Game of the Year
147842.description:
User Summary

Dishonored, Game of the Year Edition, includes additional content: The Knife of Dunwall, The Brigmore Witches, Dunwall City Trials and Void Walker's Arsenal.

147843.name: Trivia Louisville
147843.description:
Trivia Louisville is a simple roll-and-move game featuring trivia about Louisville, Kentucky. Players move their tokens around the board answering questions from different categories. Once a player has a correct answer from each category they must pass the finish square to win the game.

From the back of the box:

What Louisville-born actor starred in the film series "Cannon" and "Jake and the Fatman?"

In 1941, Louisville was the world's largest producer of what man-made product?

Who was the first woman to ride in the Kentucky Derby?

The answers to these questions and MORE can be found inside Trivia Louisville! Trivia Louisville is an exciting new game about Louisville designed for all ages. You'll enjoy this entertaining way to discover the real intrigue inside Louisville!

147844.name: Alpaca Evolution
147844.description:
User Summary

Alpaca Evolution is a game in which you play an alpaca, wandering around a field. You must attack and eat other alpacas in order to absorb their powers and evolve into more grotesque forms.

147845.name: inabsentia
147845.description:
From the game text

Human beings had gone away.
Either consumed by death or transcended to a higher state, they left their world.
But Earth wasn’t empty nor asleep. Out of a seeming lack of sentience, civilization has risen. Remembrance of the Ones Before became mystery and myth. The world was inherited, nurtured and called home. A new history began.
That was until we felt fire in the air, the sky glowing ablaze.
Something is changing. A human has come back.

inabsentia is a roleplaying game about humanity in a world totally changed. Its aim is to get players to live together a story full of sense of wonder, alienness and dramatic comparisons between what’s human and what is not. To play you will need to be three or four people with some dice, pen, paper and markers. A stereo loaded with awe and wonder-inducing music (see later) can be a great optional.
Years (or centuries, or epochs) have passed since humanity left the Earth, and a new sentient species, or more than one, inherited the whole world. We will play together to see what happens when a human being resurfaces, and i twill not be painless at all. This Human will be the past coming back, whether to haunt Earth or to change it for the better, and a single hurricane capable of tremendous change. What will be destroyed, what will change, and whether the return will be a short world-changing event or something taking roots, we will see during the game.

147846.name: Al Amarja
147846.description:
From the back of the book :

Rien n'est vraiTout est possible,Tout est permisWilliam S. Burroughs

"Je dis qu'il n'est pas illogique de penser que le monde est infini.Le juger limité, c'est postuler qu'en quelque endroit reculé les couloirs,les escaliers, les hexagones peuvent disparaître -ce qui est inconcevable, absurde. L'imaginer sans limite, c'est oublier que n'est point sans limite le nombre de livres possibles"J-L Borgès, la bibliothèque de Babel

User description :
Published by Halloween Concept.

The book is divided as follows :


Introduction (from page 6 to 9)

As the name implies, a small introduction to the book.
Noticeable informations are :


A welcome flyer given to all newcomers upon their arrival
A map of the island
Al Amarja's slang vocabulary
Setting differences between Over the Edge (2nd edition) and Conspirations



Vertige (from page 10 to 41)

Description of the main city of the island :

Barrio des armes
Barrio de l'or
Barrio des ailes brisées
Barrio des fleurs
Barrio des sciences
Barrio des grands hommes
Barrio Englouti
Barrio de la justice
Barrio des quatre points
Autour de Vertige... (les terrasses, la banlieue)




There is a description of each barrio and it's plazza, the main factions and noticeable locations.
Scenario starters and main PNJs are also dispatched through the pages.


L'île (from page 42 to 51)

Description of the island of Al Amarja :

l'Aéroport International d'Aubainne
Le manoir Goodman
L'Asile d'Aubainne
Le manoir Severson
Le mont Ralsius
Traboc
Skylla
Freedom City




As for the city, there is a description of each location with major characters and scenario starters.


Scénarios (from page 52 to 84)

Three original stories written for the french edition of the game :


Les dodos ne dorment jamais la nuit...
Qui a peur du grand Werdhard Fafhrd ?
X-rated Inferno



Additional notes

As stated on the description of Conspirations, the french core rulebook did not contain the sections about the island and the Edge city.
Those are the sections presented here.

As for the location of the island, the french edition changed the name of the Edge city back to its true name Vertige.

There's a small map of Vertige on page 85.

147847.name: Pulse (Game Chef)
147847.description:
User summary

Pulse is the winning entry among Brazilian submissions to Game Chef 2013, and was declared World Champion over the other winners in different languages (Italian, French, English). It is not a typical RPG.

Pulse is a story game in which players are time investigators. They create a map of ripples of past events, asking questions about the scenes they create, and then the others give their versions about it. The story is told backwards, and scenes they created previously start making more sense as they go deeper and deeper into details.

147848.name: Pearl Harbor Attack  Balls: DARTS – Cards
147848.description:
This is a real naval war game with a unique twist - it uses DARTs and BALLs to play. Players will attack nicely illustrated battleship profiles by tossing and dropping darts along with rolling balls. While tradition pointed darts can be used, the more graphic play uses dart(s) or ball(s) dipped in washable collorinfg for graphic splatters that mimic highly visual and realistic explosions. The game can be very simple dart toss game or be more complex by using the written game guide rules. Game play utilizes an eraser head dart but players can choose their own metal/plastic point type darts. The duration of play is between 20 minutes to more than an 60 minutes, depending if you play one, two, or all three parts. You can play the game in teams, family play or solo. A great game for adults and kids above the age of seven.

Game Parts Include: Target Illustration are legal size (8.5" X 14") black-gray-white (gray scale) colored prints - they are reproducable for non-commercial home/classroom use by the game purchaser

•Top View - Battleship target illustrations include the USS Arizona, USS Neveda, USS California, USS Tennessee, USS Maryland, USS West Virgnia, USS Oklahoma, & USS Pennsylvania

•Side View - Battleship target illustrations include the USS Nevada, USS Arizona, USS West Virginia, USS Oklahoma, and the USS California

•One mini ball and one eraser head dart included
•Game guide

The game shipped regular USPS mail in a sealed 2"w X 16"L tube

Note: Upgrade to the larger 11" X 17" colorized version of the paper battleship target illustrations for an additional $20 - email me for this upgrade option

147849.name: Wie gehen die Geschäfte?
147849.description:
User Summary

'Wie gehen die Geschäfte? Ein Unternehmerspiel voll Spannung und Humor' was published by Haus Hachenburg in the 1950s or 1960s in Germany. Another edition can be found published by SALA (Sala-Spiele GmbH & Co.)

A game reflecting the economic miracle in Germany. Similar to Monopoly you can buy/build businesses, starting from a 'Milchgeschäft' (dairy) over a 'Konfitüren-Geschäft' (jam business) to the most expensive 'Leihbücherei' (library). The player with the most money in the end wins.

147850.name: Into the Shadows
147850.description:
User description

This CD-ROM was a promotional give-away by Pegasus Spiele to accompany the launch of the German SR4A edition.
It includes the German quick-start rules, a scenario for beginners (Freier Markt) and one for advanced players (Schattenspieler).
It also features an interactive comlink as virtual handout and the song "into the Shadows" by Doria Gray feat. the Retrosic.

147851.name: Return of the Dinosaurs
147851.description:
[From the back of the box]

Two fun games with a colour fact pack.

Beautifully illustrated colour fact pack includes details on 24 dinosaurs.

4 collectable playing pieces from the Original Monsters in my Pocket range.

Two great games on a double sided board bring the Age of the Dinosaurs back to life!

The Dinosaur Dig - Simple collecting game for younger children who have to collect the pieces to build up a dinosaur.

Escape from the Volcano - Exciting dinosaur battle using the colour fact pack - can you beat the other dinosaurs and escape the exploding volcano?

Fun to play, and full of fascinating facts!

[Details on each game]

The Dinosaur Dig - Players roll the die and move around the board attempting to land on the dinosaur dig locations. Landing on a dig location enables the player to draw a "dig" card which contains one of the four dinosaur pieces that they need. Players get to keep any pieces they find that they don't already have but must return duplicates of pieces they already have. The first player to collect all four pieces is the winner.

Escape from the Volcano - Players roll a die and move their dinosaur figures around the outer track trying to land on the challenge squares. Landing on a challenge square allows them to challenge all the players to a dino-duel. The type of challenge square determines what ability the challenge is testing. Players then select a dinosaur "fact" card from their hand to enter the challenge contest. The player whose dinosaur card has the highest value in the challenge ability wins and they move their counter one space away from the volcano on the volcano track. The player who is the first to have their counter reach the tenth space on the volcano track has escaped the volcano is the winner.

147852.name: Mission: Combat!
147852.description:
A rift has opened, and unearthly creatures from an alien dimension are streaming into the world. They threaten the planet and the existence of the human race. Defend humankind against the perilous alien invasion as the Marine player! Or, on the other hand as the Portalist player, show those mortals they stand no chance!

Mission: Combat! is a tactical sci-fi card game for two players, one commanding the human Marines and the other representing the alien Portalists. Both have unique characteristics and abilities available only to their respective faction. In general, the Marines can perform ranged attacks and have strong firepower and good defensive positions. The Portalists, on the other hand, can deploy units for free, and their units can move quickly. Additionally, the area cards of the game board grant special abilities to the player who controls them. When a player manages to eliminate all enemy units on his turn, the game ends and that player wins.

To set up the game, players determine a start player, draw five unit cards to their hands, and take alternating turns to bring those units into play on their area cards. Then the game begins, with the start player using two action points (AP) in his first turn. In each subsequent turn, players have four action points at their disposal, which can be spent to carry out the following actions in any order as often as desired:


Draw a card
Play a card
Move a unit
Attack


In addition to the actions above, players can get free actions and bonuses from the area cards they control and can use special abilities that are available only to their faction only. Units are one of three types — Regular, Elite, or Colossal — and can attack only one unit type. For instance, an Elite unit that can deal damage to Regular units cannot deal damage to Elite or Colossal units.

To achieve victory, players need to consider the defense and attack types of their army, and the faction strengths and weaknesses, along with the abilities that they get from the terrain that they control. Choose your side and wipe your opponent from the surface of the planet!

147853.name: Le trèfle noir
147853.description:
User description :
Le trèfle noir (The black clover) is a scenario that takes place after Les otages (The hostages), a scenario from the base set of the game.

The players take the roles of members of the Atrénates tribe.

The story takes place during the winter season, while the war between the Atrénates and their enemies, the Ostrites, is slowed by the snow.

Seeking answer in the stars, the wisest of the Atrénates learn that the Ostrites are given power by a "black clover" they've never heard of.

The village's council sends the characters on a mission to seek the help of a great druid who should know about the black clover .

147854.name: Atomic Race
147854.description:
Atomic Race is played on a 5x5 board. Each player starts with ten pieces occupying the two rows closest to them. A move consists of taking a single piece or the top piece from an "atom" (stack) and moving it in any combination of forwards and sideways moves until it reaches an empty space or a space with an opponent's piece visible (moving through spaces where the player's own color is visible).

The central row of the board (the "plasma zone") cannot contain atoms, so a single piece there controls its space until it moves.

The object is to exit one's pieces off the opposing end of the board. Since the game is short, the designer suggests playing a series of games using a scoring system.

The game was published in the March/April 1979 issue of GAMES.

147855.name: Re: Your Brains
147855.description:
Based on the song by Jonathan Coulton, Re: Your Brains pits 2-5 players against each other and the zombie horde. Players play food and office supply cards face up in front of them to give them bonuses, play weapon cards to destroy zombies, and play any card face down in front of their opponents to create more zombies that want to eat their brains.

Each player starts out as a heroic human and can win if they are the sole survivor, OR they can become overrun by zombies and become a zombie master. Each zombie master has a different victory condition.

This game should not be confused with the other card game of the same name. Same inspiration; different implementation.

147856.name: XandO
147856.description:
XandO is played on a 6x6 square grid. The game begins with the players taking turns to blacken four squares of the grid (two each). After that the players take turns to mark their symbols (X and O) in empty squares, with the option of blackening a square instead on their last turns.

Once the grid is full players score for consecutive lines of their symbols in any direction. However, while even numbers of symbols score positively, odd numbers (greater than one) score negatively.

A game consists of two rounds. In the second round of a game, the same four squares are blackened as were chosen at the start of the first round and the player who went second now goes first.

The game was published in the March/April 1979 issue of GAMES.

147857.name: Quink
147857.description:
Quink is played using five pieces each of five different colors on a 7x7 board. At the start of the game the pieces are arranged in cross formations on specific board spaces, with each cross containing one piece of each color and the center of each cross being a different color.

A move consists of a player moving a piece orthogonally any number of empty spaces. There are five special spaces which when landed on let the player make another move with the same piece or a piece of the same color, counting it as part of the same move.

The object is to get the five pieces of each color in a connected group. The game can be played as a solitaire puzzle or by multiple players; the designer suggests playing with two by trading off setting up boards for the opponent (the goal being to solve the opponent's puzzle in fewer moves than they solve yours), or any number by each trying to solve the same puzzle in the fewest moves.

147858.name: Battle
147858.description:
Battle is a small, simplified version of Battle: The Game of Generals. The players each have six infantry and four armor units, which they secretly set up at opposite ends of a 9x12 hex grid. On a turn a player may move any or all of their pieces and can eliminate an opponent's piece by getting a greater combat value of pieces adjacent to it. Combat values are different in the three different terrain types.

The object of the game is to move a piece into the opponent's headquarters space.

The game was published in the 'May/June 1981 issue of GAMES.

147859.name: Order and Chaos
147859.description:
Order and Chaos is played on a 6x6 square grid. On a turn a player writes either an X or an O in any empty space. The object of the first player (Order) is to complete a line of five Xs or five Os in any direction. The object of the other player (Chaos) is to prevent this.

The game was published in the September/October 1981 issue of GAMES.

147860.name: Asphalt 8: Airborne
147860.description:
LEAVE GRAVITY IN THE DUST

High-performance cars from top licensed manufacturers such as Lamborghini, Ferrari & Pagani
Hit the ramps & take the race to the air: Perform barrel rolls & 360 degree jumps
Race in 9 different settings such as Venice & the Nevada Desert
8 seasons & 180 events in the Career Mode
A detailed damage system
New Infected & Drift Gate game modes
Simultaneous multiplayer and asynchronous races




Source: The Game Website.

147861.name: Unruly!
147861.description:
Unruly! is a party card game for all ages, where the object is fairly simple, but the rules are constantly changing, and the laughter is infectious!

In theory, winning the game should be easy. You just have to play a complete sequence of 3 Thing Cards, but getting there isn't so simple.

There are several obstacles that can, and will, get in your way.

The rules change with every player’s turn - rules ranging from silly to downright hilarious! Breaking a rule comes with a Penalty. Players draw a Penalty roll, with the results ranging from losing just one card, to losing everything and having to start from scratch.

There are Event Cards like "Switch places with another player" or "Take a Hike" where everyone leaves their cards and moves over one place. These are great for messing with the other players.

And there are Unruly Cards, which players can use at any time, when they catch another player doing the behavior or action listed on the Card, forcing the other player to make a Penalty roll.

You’re kept on your toes 100% of the time. You always have something to do, even when it’s not your turn. Your plans and progress can change with the drop of a card or an errant scratch of your head.

Competition can be fierce, yet you’ll laugh so hard that everyone will feel like a winner!

147862.name: War of the Black Holes
147862.description:
War of the Black Holes is played on a board with four concentric rings of spaces. Each player has a single spacecraft piece which moves each turn, either within a single ring or with one change to an adjacent ring. The number of spaces that can be moved depends on the ring the move ends in, with the inner rings requiring faster movement than the outer rings.

After moving a "black hole" piece is placed in a space adjacent to one's spacecraft. These pieces can be moved over but a move cannot be ended on one; a player wins when their opponent cannot move to an empty space.

The game was published in the July/August 1982 issue of GAMES.

147863.name: Loop-the-Loops
147863.description:
Loop-the-Loops is played on a piece of paper on which one player draws five intersecting loops (or more if desired), in any way they want.

Players then on their turns start at an intersection and color the lines, going past two intersections and ending at a third. It is possible to switch to another loop at an intersection. The first player can start at any intersection; after that each player must start where the previous player ended.

If the coloring reaches an intersection which can't be moved from the player's turn ends and the other player may start anywhere.

When a played finishes a loop they score 1 point (or 2 points for the last loop if there are an even number of loops).

The game was published in the November 1982 issue of GAMES.

147864.name: Spud's Quest
147864.description:
Spud's Quest is an indie adventure game that draws it's inspiration from retro classics like the Dizzy series, The Legend of Zelda, and Metroid. The project was successfully funded on Kickstarter in November 2012.

It's a flip screen puzzle adventure where players take on the role of Spud and his friend Prince Charming, who has been cursed by an evil wizard and turned into a frog. The pair set on a journey to uncover four ancient elemental essences that have the power to banish the evil and remove the curse.

Source: The Game Website.

147865.name: Rondo
147865.description:
Rondo is played on a board of five concentric rings of twelve spaces each. One player has black pieces and starts on the innermost ring, the other has white pieces and starts on the outermost ring. The object is to connect the innermost and outermost rings with an unbroken chain of your pieces.

Pieces can move outward, inward, diagonally inward or outward, or around the ring they are in. However, Black can only move outward and clockwise and White can only move inward and counterclockwise. Pieces must jump opposing pieces when able to do so (the jumped pieces are not captured).

The game was published in the December 1982 issue of GAMES.

147866.name: Score Five
147866.description:
Score Five is played on a 6x6 square grid in which someone has randomly placed the numbers 1-9, four times each.

The first player starts by circling the number in one of the four corners and starting a running total with that number. The second player circles an adjacent number and adds it to the running total. This continues until the running total reaches 170, at which point the game ends.

When a player makes the running total a multiple of five, they add that running total to their score. Whoever has the higher score when the game ends, wins.

The game was published in the January 1983 issue of GAMES.

147867.name: Rescue
147867.description:
Rescue is played on a 5x9 grid. Players each have nine pieces which begin the game in stacks of one, two, or three pieces.

On a turn a player moves one of their stacks as many spaces as the number of pieces in the stack, in any orthogonal direction or combination of such directions. Only empty spaces can be crossed; an opponent's stack can be landed on, which captures the pieces in it.

After moving a player may take one piece and put it in any legal space (empty or on top of one of their one or two-piece stacks).

Certain spaces on the board have numbers in the players' colors. If a player ends a stack's move on a space of their color and the number of pieces in the stack, the stack is "rescued" and removed from the board.

The game ends when one player has no pieces on the board (due to rescue and/or capture). The player who rescued the most pieces wins.

The game was published in the February 1983 issue of GAMES.

147868.name: Sque-e-e-eze Play
147868.description:
Sque-e-e-eze Play is played on a 7x7 square grid. Players begin by each making a (different) mark in any space. On each subsequent turn, a player begins at their last mark, moves any number of empty spaces in any straight line, and places a new mark in the end space. (The previous mark is crossed out.)

The object is to end on your opponent's last mark (an exception to the rule about only moving in empty spaces) or prevent your opponent from playing.

The game was published in the May 1983 issue of GAMES.

147869.name: Neverwinter Nights: Complete
videogamecompilation: Neverwinter Nights 2: Mask of the Betrayer
Neverwinter Nights: Hordes of the Underdark
147869.description:
From the back of the box:

The Best RPG.
The Ultimate Collection.

The most beloved RPG collection ever.
Experience of of the most popular and critically acclaimed roleplaying adventures of our time. Inhabit dreamlike world of myth and mystery within the greatest city of the Forgotten Realms (c).

Adventure awaits!
Deadly creatures, foreboding omens, and perilous danger are yours to overcome. Defeat hundreds of monsters and nefarious villains across fantastic lands and limitless online campaigns.

The ultimate collection.
The entire Neverwinter Nights (c) catalog, encompassing the award-winning Neverwinter Nights (c), the critically acclaimed Neverwinter Nights (c) 2, expansion packs for both games and the never-released at retail expansion pack Mysteries of Westgate (TM), are yours in one premium collection.

147870.name: Breakthrough
147870.description:
Breakthrough is played on a 5x9 board. Each player has ten pieces which start in the rows nearest them. The object is to get a piece to the row farthest away from you. On a turn a piece can move any distance diagonally as long as it does not pass over any piece or land on an opponent's piece.

The fourth and seventh rows of the board are "wall" rows, and pieces which reach the opposing wall cannot move forward. The only way to get a piece across the wall (necessary to win) is via explosion. Each space has a maximum capacity (depending on which column it is in), and when you get that many of your pieces in a space it explodes, sending the pieces to orthogonally adjacent spaces. Opposing pieces can be captured this way, and chain reactions can occur.

The game was published in the January 1984 issue of GAMES.

147871.name: Flipside
147871.description:
2 player game played on the spaces of an 8x8 board.

Materials

4 chess pawns, 2 black and 2 white.
64 bi-colored reversi pieces.

Definition
piece = a bi-colored reversi piece

Setup

Set the empty board between the players.

Set two like color pawns diagonally adjacent to each other onto two of the four center squares on the board.

Set two pieces at each row and column along the outer edge of the board .

Play

One player plays black the other white.

Black moves first, then play alternates.

On your turn,

Move a friendly pawn in a straight line orthogonally or diagonally ending the movement on an empty square. Then take a piece from the outer edge of the board, flip it to your color and move this piece in a straight line orthogonally ending the move on an empty space. The piece last moved and the pawn last moved should now be in line of sight of each other.

When both players pass in succession the game ends.

Restrictions

- A piece is not in line of sight with a pawn if another pawn or piece is in-between them.

- Neither a pawn nor a piece may jump over another pawn or piece.

Objective

The player with the most pieces in his color on the board at the end of the game is the winner.

The inspiration for this game comes from Walter Zamkauskas Amazons

147872.name: Castles of Darkness
147872.description:
User Summary

Set a land free from an evil wizard in this Text Adventure game with graphics and animation.

147873.name: La longue traque
147873.description:
From the back of the book :
Les Formoires veulent reconquérir la terre et exterminer l'homme, cet usurpateur. Ils sont peu nombreux, mais rusés et féroces comme des loups affamés.

Des forêts gauloises aux rivages d'Irlande, LA LONGUE TRAQUE entraîne les personnages à la poursuite de ces guerriers mythiques.

Une chasse dangereuse, où les chasseurs pourraient bien devenir les proies.

LA LONGUE TRAQUE, plus qu'une poursuite infernale, une Légende !

User description :
The book is subtitled "Sur la piste des Formoîrés" and contains four scenarios:


Le hêtre rouge, from Alexis Lang (page 4 to 17)
Le spectre du naufragé, from Philippe Alliot (page 18 to 25)
Ar-Gulenn, from Olivier Maillard (page 26 to 37)
La menace, from Antoine Duchon (page 38 to 48)


They can be played independantly from one another or as a campaign that will lead the characters from their village in Gaul to Ireland and then the northern islands.

The cover and all interior's illustration are from Philippe Julien while Stéphane Truffert drew the maps.

147874.name: Swish
147874.description:
Swish and its twin game Squeeze are non-mancala bead capture games. They are played on a base-5 hex hex board divided in a 37-cells inner area and a 24-cells edge. One player makes an initial setup with three 'hex rooks' of both players on the edge and 19 beads in the inner area. The other player may choose either to move first or the color to play with.

In Swish the rooks capture by the long leap. They may capture both beads and pieces, though not simultaneously. Multiple captures are possible. The player who captures 10 or more beads wins.

The game was published in the July 1984 issue of GAMES.

147875.name: Morro
147875.description:
Morro is played on an 8x8 square grid using two pieces per player and 19 neutral pieces. To start the game one player places all four players' pieces on the edge of the board and any number of neutral pieces on non-edge spaces. The other player may then either move first and choose which color to play, or may take the remaining neutral pieces (counting towards the victory condition) and let the other player choose a color and move first.

A turn consists of moving either of your pieces in any straight line over empty spaces. After a move, if the moving piece and any other piece (including one of the opposing pieces) enclose an unbroken line of neutral pieces (or opposing pieces), the enclosed pieces are captured.

The object of the game is to capture a majority of the 19 neutral pieces.

As a variant, one piece of each player moves as described above, and the other can jump over pieces (jumped pieces are not captured).

The game was published in the July 1984 issue of GAMES.

147876.name: Crazy Quilt
147876.description:
Crazy Quilt is played on a 4x4 grid of squares, with each square being divided into four triangles. Players take turns coloring triangles (with each player using a different color). When all triangles have been colored, players score points for certain shapes made from four triangles each, with overlaps allowed.

The game was published in the January 1985 issue of GAMES.

147877.name: The Cave of Time
147877.description:
User Summary

Return four items stolen by the time grouches and return them in this adaptation of the “Choose Your Own Adventure” book of the same name.

147878.name: The Caves of Olympus
147878.description:
User Summary

In this Text Adventure with graphics you are a robot and you must rediscover the secrets of Olympus to help repel an invading intergalactic force.

147879.name: Reiner Knizia's Penguin
147879.description:
A game for 2 to 6 players based on a card game designed by a famous board and card game designer Reiner Knizia.
Try to get as many of your colored penguins to the iceberg as possible.

On your turn you play one of your colored penguins to build up the iceberg. If the bottom row contains fewer than eight penguins (seven in a 2-player game), a new penguin can be placed in the bottom row to the left or to the right of the penguins that are already there. A penguin may be played in a higher row over two adjacent penguins if at least one of the penguins below is of the same color as the newly played penguin.
If it is your turn and you are unable to play a penguin, you are eliminated from the current round and receive as many penalty points as you have penguins left. The round continues until all players are eliminated or get rid of all their penguins. Players who succeed in playing all their penguins may get rid of two of their penalty points from earlier rounds.
The game lasts as many rounds as there are players with the starting player changing each round. The player with the smallest number of penalty points at the end is the winner.

You can:

• select a game variant (4 or 5 colors)

• select the number of players (2 to 6)

• play against AI or other human players on the same device

• win achievements

Source: The Publisher Website.

147880.name: Pencil Football
147880.description:
Pencil Football is played on a sheet of lined paper. The lines are numbered along one edge, goals are drawn near the ends, and then irregularly-spaced line segments are drawn along the lines to create obstacles.

Kick-offs, extra points, and field goals are accomplished by placing a pencil at a certain point, closing your eyes, lifting the pencil, and attempting to bring it down as close as possible to the goal line (for a kick-off) or in the goal area (for a field goal or extra point).

Regular plays are done by placing the pencil at the spot where the ball is, closing your eyes, and attempting to draw a path towards the goal that avoids obstacles. Each player gets four chances (downs) to advance the ball in this way, then the opponent takes over.

The game can be played solitaire using a provided board.

The game was published in the January 1987 issue of GAMES.

147881.name: Max: A Two-Player Game
147881.description:
Max is played on an 8x8 grid filled with positive and negative integers, except for one space marked with a star. One player starts by crossing out any number in the row with the star and adding to his or her total. The other player then crosses out any number in the column where the first player's number is. The players continue choosing numbers based on the row or column where the previous play was until one of them cannot move.

A game consists of two rounds; in the second round players switch so that the player who played rows now plays columns and vice-versa. The high score after both rounds wins.

The game was published in the April 1994 issue of GAMES.

The game appears to be nothing more than a pencil-and-paper version of Mattix, which was not designed by the "designer" of this game.

147882.name: The Great Snark Rescue
147882.description:
The Great Snark Rescue is played on a hex map depicting a park. Certain hexes are designated as starting spaces for snarks, snark trackers (which are owned by the players), and transportation pieces. On each turn players move their trackers and attempt to land them on snarks, which rescues them. The object is to rescue the majority of the snarks.

The terrain affects movement; a tracker must stop when entering a forest hex and cannot normally enter water hexes. A tracker can move onto a transportation piece and then use it, which may let it move farther (e.g. a bicycle can move any distance, but only along a path) and/or circumvent movement restrictions (e.g., a boat can go in the water and a hot-air balloon can cross water and forest hexes).

Variants allow for free setup of the various pieces.

The game was published in the first issue (April/May 1995) of Zigzag, a GAMES spin-off for children.

boardgameimplementation: Lost Legacy: Second Chronicle – Vorpal Sword & Whitegold Spire
boardgameintegration: Lost Legacy: Binbo Tantei to Inbo no Shiro
Lost Legacy: Binbo Tantei to Inbo no Shiro
147883.description:
Lost Legacy: Hyakunen Senso to Ryu no Miko includes two sets of 16 cards: Vorpal Sword and Staff of Dragons. Players can use one set or the other or combine them in various ways to alter the powers available in the game. Shuffle all the cards together (other than the second "Lost Legacy"), and you can include up to six players in the same game. Cards from Lost Legacy: Hyakunen Senso to Ryu no Miko can also be combined with Lost Legacy and Lost Legacy: Binbo Tantei to Inbo no Shiro.


Rules Summary

In Lost Legacy: Hyakunen Senso to Ryu no Miko, you start the game with one card in hand from a deck of sixteen cards. On a turn, you do the following:


Draw: Draw the top card from the deck and add it to your hand.
Play: Choose one of the two cards in hand to play and place it face up in front of you.
Effect: Carry out the played card's effect, after which the card is considered as discarded.
End: If there is at least one card left in the deck, the turn goes to the next player; if not, the investigation phase starts. Using the investigation speed indicated on the card each player has in hand, players take turns guessing which player (whether yourself or someone else) holds the "Lost Legacy" card; this card might also be in the "Ruins", a location that holds one card at the start of the game and possibly acquires more cards during play. The player who guesses correctly wins; if no one finds the Lost Legacy, then everybody loses.
147883.name: Lost Legacy: Hyakunen Senso to Ryu no Miko
boardgameexpansion: Lost Legacy: The Qualities of an Adventurer

147884.description:
In Ore: The Mining Game, players assume the roles of clever industrialists competing for fame and fortune. Ore takes place during the industrial revolution, and aims to simulate the complexities of effective supply chain management.

Players take turns carefully placing their workers on one of several "location" cards:
- In mines, to collect one of five different resources (lead, coal, copper, iron, or gold);
- In manufacturing, to construct new assets that convey a strategic advantage over opponents;
- In research & development, to expand their operations and create new avenues for growth;
- In distribution, to secure lucrative contracts that allow for players' operations to scale.

Each player starts with $20 and 2 workers. Early on, players have very limited means and can only sell one resource at a time. However, by mining resources, acquiring assets, securing contracts, and expanding their operations through new initiatives, players become more readily able to generate more and more amounts of income.

Mines become exhausted after they have been mined for a certain number of turns, and, once exhausted, they are replaced by subsequent mine cards. Similarly, a limited number of assets, initiatives, and contract cards are available for players to take, and, after being acquired, they are replaced until their respective decks run out.

The game ends as soon as any of the following occur:
- The asset deck runs out;
- The contract deck runs out;

At that point in time, the player with the greatest amount of money, victory points from assets, and completed contracts is declared the winner.
147884.name: Ore: The Mining Game

147886.name: Tyrant Soul
147886.description:
Tyrant Soul pits a group of unique and powerful heroes against against a variety of encounters that evoke the feeling of an epic, set-piece "boss fight." Each challenging encounter requires long-term strategic thinking, precise tactical execution and optimal usage of resources to conquer.

Tyrant Soul was inspired by end-game raiding popularized by MMOs, but also draws influences from a diverse collection of RPGs, miniatures skirmish games and TCG/LCGs - along with its own mechanics, including (optional) digital integration features.

Key Features:
> Tile-based battle map makes for a different battlefield in every encounter.
> Each playable character has a unique skillset and mechanics that make them play differently from the others. From the rapid-fire, combo-based style of the fiery Kindleborne to the reality-bending Traceless who leaves behind "shadow copies" of herself that can copy her attacks and movements.
> Gather power from the "Soulstream" that permeates the world (represented by a set of poker-like cards with custom suits) - put together the right combinations to activate powerful Heroic versions of your base skills that add new twists and enable new combos.
> The "recharge" mechanic is a quick, intuitive and visual take on cooldown mechanics popular in video games.
> 5+ epic boss monsters and encounters - each with its own theme and mechanics
> Every encounter follows an "AI script" with a combination of set and randomized events to create a dynamic challenge - no "GM" or "Overlord" needed. Digital extensions make it a snap to run the encounter from a tablet, smartphone or laptop.
> Compete with other players around the world by taking on special, super-difficult "achievement" challenges. Our online leaderboard will ensure that everyone knows your accomplishments.
> Playable as a modular single session game or an extended campaign where players grow in power and attain new powerful items and skills.
> Expanding World: New boss encounters and character classes to be released regularly!
> Alternate Game Modes: Take on your friends in PvP combat, or enter the Gauntlet and face an endless horde of randomized foes

147887.description:
Allegiance: A Realm Divided is a fully self-contained game of strategy and epic fantasy battles, where players assume the roles of powerful heroes fighting for dominion over the realm.

Each hero represents a different fantasy character class, with their own unique abilities, weapons, and play styles. Players level-up their hero by unlocking increasingly powerful abilities, enlist allies to fight by their side, and engage their enemies in battle.

With 10 different playable heroes, a wide range of strategic moves to choose from, and a high degree of player-interaction built in, a game of Allegiance will never play out the same way twice.

Featuring a hybrid card game and board game format, Allegiance has all of the depth of a collectible card game in one box. Rich in detail and beautifully depicted by some of the leading fantasy artists in the industry, Allegiance is an immersive experience for fantasy fans and strategy gamers alike.
147887.name: Allegiance: A Realm Divided

147889.description:
#Captains Log, Entry 37

When we set out, I thought this mission is a wild goose chase but now, when we are so close I think this actually might be worth all the effort the Corporation has made. I have been looking over the photos the probe sent and I must admit, there definitely is something buried under the surface. I am glad the Corporation trusted me with this endeavor. The crew is a bit on the edge, but it is understandable, this has never been done before. We should be landing in a few days, and I cant wait for the digging to begin. Sadly other corps have also found the resources to make the mission a reality so this will be kind of a race. I am certain we will win.

#End of entry 37

In Dig Mars, players perform different actions to dig out discovery tiles. Discovery tiles are worth varying numbers of fortune points, but fortune points can also be used to upgrade a player's equipment. When to do what? Timing is key. The different actions are:


Move – move one of your tokens to an adjacent stack in a horizontal or vertical direction.



Dig - reveal the top tile of the stack with at least one of your tokens on it.



Carry out – choose any revealed tile with at least one of your tokens on it and take it into your possession, giving you fortune points.



Upgrade – pay the corresponding number of fortune points (by discarding tiles) to boost your equipment tile to the next level (e.g., from 2 to 3).


When a player has collected a certain amount of fortune points, depending on number of players, the game ends and he wins!
147889.name: Dig Mars
boardgamepodcastepisode: The Boardgame Review Room: Dig Mars

147890.name: Netburbia
147890.description:
Summary
Netburbia is a simple and unique social game where players create and vote on posts. Depending on players' power they are able to conquer and become ruler of different regions.

Website
Netburbia

147891.name: Sub Rosa (Issue 13 - September 2013)
147891.description:
Issue 13 September 2013 Contents
Under the Rose Page 4 From the Line Editor Page 5 By David Chart
Unearthing the Thirteenth House Page 6 By Gerald Wylie
The Slumbering Legacy Page 22 By Ben McFarland and James Parks
Redcap Training Packages Page 36 By Lachie Hayes The Watchers in Diana’s Sphere Page 48 By Tobias Wheeler and Matt Ryan
The Divisible Men Page 60 By Timothy Ferguson
Díedne the Theurge Page 62 By Erik Dahl
The Journal of Vulcan Page 74
The Cult of Belenos Page 78 By Mark Baker A
Chthonic Path to Corruption? Page 88 By Christian Rosenkjaer Andersen
The House We Never Had Page 99 By Naomi Rivkis The Lost City of Kitezh Page 102 By Chad Bowser
Mappa Mundi Page 107

147892.name: Councils & Contracts
147892.description:
The highest decision-making organ in a city is the City Council, which lays down the general operative and financial outlines for a city and decides on its main objectives. The true power, however, is a little further down the hierarchy in the different councils working under the City Council.

In the card-driven game Councils & Contracts, the players act as developers who try to push their own objectives — namely, receiving lucrative building contracts. Therefore, it's important for them to gain influence in every one of the councils since doing so is crucial for deciding the assignment of building contracts. Naturally, all of the developers are keen to gain that influence...

Councils & Contracts is the winner of the third game author's competition "Edition Kofferspiele" organized by Mücke Spiele/Spielmaterial. In that competition the limitation was that the game fits in 11 x 7,5 x 3 cm metal box. Similar to Hart an der Grenze smuggling boxes. It is easy and light to take with you and has a lot of game inside the box.

Components:

1 City Hall card
5 Council cards
25 Influence cards (5 per player)
36 Building project cards
30 Employees (6 in 5 different colors)
5 Point markers (in 5 colours)
25 Transparent markers (to track influence)
1 Score board




Basic gameplay:

Players start with four workers and can lose or gain more through actions.

There are four possible actions but only two of them are available depending whether player has workers in his play area or not.

If a player has workers on his play area he must place them either on council rooms (two in one council room or one in three council rooms) or start a building project using influence and depending on project one or two workers.

If a player doesn't have any workers he must take them out either from one council room (giving influence to each player with presence in that room) or finish a building project and take the depicted building action, which usually returns the workers back to players playing area.

There are eight buildings projects shown and after the building deck is depleted and only four building projects are shown the game ends. There are then two extra actions per player and final scoring.

Game variants:

First/short game: Remove cards 29 - 37 and the promos.

Mixed setup: After shuffling the A and B decks (separately) remove four cards from both of them.

Gears council: Use the gears (brown) council like the 5 player council instructs but receive gears influence.

147893.name: Call of Juarez: Gunslinger
videogamehonor: 2013 Global Game Awards Best Historical Game of the Year Nominee
147893.description:
User Summary

A first person shooter being narrated by the main character, bounty hunter Silas Greaves, as he tells stories of his past actions to patrons in a bar in 1910. The game allows you to gain new abilities for your character, to go into slow motion, to duel enemies, and has a quicktime bullet dodge feature that allows you to avoid what would have been a lethal shot.

At times people may doubt Silas' story causing him to rewind time in the game and edit certain events changing the scenario or gameplay.

147894.name: Typisch Deutsch?! Das Kaya Spiel
147894.description: Is this typically German or what? In the party trivia game Typisch Deutsch?! Das Kaya Spiel, developed in collaboration with comedian Kaya Yanar, players travel throughout Germany examining peculiarities of different regions, culture, language and customs.

147895.name: Bad Company
147895.description:
From publisher blurb:

You didn't think something happened to go old Killshot Files, did you? Far from, the world's deadliest tabletop RPG carries on with the 2nd supplement pushing the game - and your career - further than ever before.

We stocked this sucker to the brim with 60 pages of extended mayhem and death, from new rules for using poison in your career, to an expanded look at the eight original focuses with seven new ones to stretch out your resources. Plus there's a collection of six specialties, a pair of Fresh Marks, and finally a complete job called "Bad Company" pitting your Team against a crew of hackers looking to sell off some vital data to the highest bidder. What's the data? That's not your job to know, remember? What's important is that it's a complete job for 4-6 assassins with 35+ training points under their belt.

147896.name: The Coming Storm
147896.description:
From publisher blurb:

A Savage Worlds One Sheet by Miles M. Kantir

An Epic High Fantasy Shaintar adventure, using the Western Keep map set by DramaScape.

After a tranquil night’s rest, it’s early morning and the Rangers are traveling a wide valley alongside a lazy river, when they stop short and double check their charts. There’s no mention if it, yet there’s an old-style keep overlooking the river, with sturdy stone walls, towers, and a full moat. This is not a structure that got built over night.

147897.name: Pass to Danger
147897.description:
From publisher blurb:

A Savage Worlds One Sheet by Steve Perrin

An Epic High Fantasy Shaintar adventure, using the Mountain Pass map set by DramaScape.

In the Malakar Dominion, on the trade road between the towns of Kol and Tragor that sit between the Longtree Forest and the Black Mountains, there is a fork on the road that leads toward the mountains. This road is little used between the months of Raining Leaves and Falling Ice. There are no settlements or farms along the road, and between the aforementioned months the Mountains are choked with snow. Landslides and deceptively deep snowdrifts are common.

With the thaw comes a return of traffic through the area... and there also comes a new, unprecedented danger.

147898.name: Only the Worthy
147898.description:
From publisher blurb:

A Savage Worlds One Sheet by Scott Corum

An Epic High Fantasy Shaintar adventure, using the Dragon Throne map set by DramaScape.

It has lain dormant for almost a millennium, but its legend has not. Who shall find the Dragon Throne, and who shall be worthy to be its Master?

147899.name: Fire in the Darkness
147899.description:
From publisher blurb:

A Savage Worlds One Sheet by Sean Patrick Fannon

An Epic High Fantasy Shaintar adventure, using the Crypts map set by DramaScape.

Somewhere in the bowls of the earth, an ancient complex of crypts has become disturbed. Filled with the remains of beings dedicated to Darkness, it is the forces of Flame that now occupy the place and seek to make use of its inherent power. The Heroes must make their way into the tunnels below, enter the Crypts of Jazhak Val, and wrest control of a powerful Locus from a minor demon seeking to gain greater power for himself in the Abyss.

147900.name: A Quiet Drink With Enemies
147900.description:
From publisher blurb:

A Savage Worlds One Sheet by Eddy Webb

An Epic High Fantasy Shaintar adventure, using the Hillside Tavern map set by DramaScape.

Ah, the Flickering Flame Tavern, a pub carved into the side of a mountain. It’s a nice, quiet place to unwind after a long adventure, until a heated argument leads to a surprising revelation.

147901.name: A Darkness Comes to Stormwall
147901.description:
From publisher blurb:

A Savage Worlds One Sheet by Rob Davis

An Epic High Fantasy Shaintar adventure, using the Castle Ruins map set by DramaScape.

The ruins of Stormwall Keep have sat silent for over two hundred years. Its crumbling walls no longer shelter anyone from danger. But on this night, darkness has come to the ruins and it is up to a group of unsuspecting Rangers to put a stop to it.

147902.name: Hero Pack 5
147902.description:
From publisher blurb:

Ad Infinitum Adventures and ICONS artist Dan Houser, are proud to present Hero Pack 5, a collection of characters created for the game by ICONS fans!

In this 87-page PDF, you'll find dozens characters fully statted for ICONS (using the updated guidelines from the Great Power sourcebook) and illustrated in the signature ICONS style by Dan Houser! Moreover, the characters are paired as foes: three pairs of solo hero/villain enemies and seven pairs of teams (fourteen total) as arch-foes, all ready to use in your game!

147903.name: Otherworldly Invocations
147903.description:
From publisher blurb:

Patrons Like You’ve Never Seen Them Before

Wizards get their magic from studying tomes. Sorcerers inherit their magic from their parents. Clerics get their magic from their god. Druids get their magic from nature. And witches get their magic from an eldritch pact made with a supernatural patron…at least in theory. But the mechanics behind the witch’s patron class feature just don’t promote that sort of thing. When choosing between patrons like “wisdom” and “moon,” and knowing that the only real effect is a handful of bonus spells known, the excitement of choosing an otherworldly patron seems to just fade away.

This book takes witch patrons in a wild new direction that greatly expands them into something that can be fun and interesting at the game table. The book contains 10 new patrons, each of which is an individual entity rather than a vague concept, and each of which has extensive descriptions of his or her personality, background, and goals, as well as the types of familiars that the patron typically grants, information on other followers of the patron, and so on.

Even more exciting, choosing one of the patrons in this book does more than grant you bonus spells. Each patron comes with a number of mechanical benefits and drawbacks associated with making a magical pact with them, which function similarly to an archetype, meaning that one’s choice of patron is meaningful mechanically, as well as flavorfully. With 10 patrons to choose from, there are plenty of options, including:

Al’Rajan, a crafy efreeti cursed to grant any wish asked of him, who attempts to pass this burden on to those to whom he grants magic.
Irashen, a celestial general who is happy to loan out some of heaven’s power to mortals who will use it to fight evil.
Jodan, an insane spirit obsessed with humor, whose magic is incredibly unreliable.
Tesherazz, a powerful devil who empowers witches in his employ with the ability to make magically-binding contracts.
Thyrvinistar, a powerful dragon who is willing to share his magic in exchange for nothing more than raw gold.
And many more!




So if you’ve ever wished that your witch’s patron was a little less one-dimensional, or just want some new options and archetypes for the witch class, this is the book for you. Even if you don’t care one bit for witches, GMs looking for powerful cosmic entities to serve as enemies, allies, patrons, or temptations for their party will find a wealth of ideas and useful information on the various entities included in this book. Don’t miss out on this chance to make your game a little more magical.

147904.name: Pretty Ugly
147904.description:
Mirror, mirror on the wall, who is the fairest one of all? Of course, me! In Pretty Ugly every player thinks so, but only one will be declared the next top model by the strict jury.

Pretty Ugly is a satirical game about beauty contests and Top Model TV shows. The game is interactive, funny, and contains a good mixture of strategy and luck. The game mimics the absurd real-world beauty mania: players can never completely reach the beauty ideal, the beauty ideal changes over time, and finally, beauty sells!

In Pretty Ugly the players represent models that want to win as many beauty contests as possible. Each turn a player either takes 3 open cards to add to their hand, or plays an action from the hand to adapt their looks to the random (and maybe not so “pretty”) beauty ideal. But be careful: other players can be mean and “uglify” you! After three rounds there is always a beauty contest where the player with the most matching aspects with the beauty ideal wins the most money, and the player with the least matching aspects wins the least money. Then the beauty ideal changes completely and players need to adapt to the new ideal again. After 9 rounds and 3 beauty contests, the player who has won the most money in total wins the game.

147906.name: Märchenball
147906.description: In Märchenball, the princesses have come from across the country to the fairy tale ball. Each princess wants to dance with Prince Charming, so he's a busy guy on the dance floor. Find your way into his arms, though, and you'll receive a star from him as a thank you. The first princess to collect four stars from Prince Charming has also won his heart — and the game!

147907.name: AFL the Board Game
147907.description:
Choose your favourite team then line up against your rival for the opening bounce. The electronic scoreboard will sound the siren, just like a real game, and you’re away. Position your defenders to thwart your opposition’s attacking moves and then try to gain possession of the footy and successfully negotiate your way down the ground, positioning yourself for a shot at goal.

Listen out for the umpire’s whistle along the way and avoid giving away free kicks. Once in position for a shot at goal the fun begins. Place your ball on the Super kicker, go back and line up. Will the pressure get to you, will the crowd boos put you off or will you hold your nerve like a champion forward and put it through the middle of the big sticks for a 6 pointer to hear the crowd go wild?

147908.name: La malédiction de Cahir
147908.description:
From the back of the book :
Cumaill, le plus brave d'entre vous est gravement blessé.
Airmed, la druidesse, espère que les pouvoirs de l'esprit de la
source viendront à bout de ces blessures. En partant, vous êtes bien
loin de vous douter que l'Autre-Monde est au bout du chemin, un
Autre-Monde étrange, à la fois si proche et si différent...

Ce scénario se déroule en Irlande, contrée magique où se
rejoignent légendes celtiques et légendes arthuriennes.

Conçue pour les joueurs de Légendes Celtiques (version Légendes
et Premières Légendes), cette aventure hors du commun, est une
excellente introduction à l'atmosphère de La Table Ronde.

LA MALEDICTION DE CAHIR, plus qu'un scénario : une légende !

User description :
This scenario can be played with Légendes and is also meant to be an introduction to Légendes de la table ronde.

The cover is from Michel Riu while interior illustrations are from Michel Riu and Stéphane Truffer.

rpgitemversion: Game Chef submission - English translation PDF
147910.name: Kimochi no koryôshi: Les Petits Chasseurs d'Émotions
rpg: Kimochi no koryôshi: Les Petits Chasseurs d'Émotions
147910.description:
From the game's introduction

The world has lost its color and its soul. People have gathered in cities, leaving the countryside little by little. Slowly, insidiously, people are losing their humanity. They commute, they work, they sleep; the townspeople settling for a life on autopilot, where cooperation, conversation and other simple things in life have completely disappeared. Little by little, they are losing certain feelings and certain emotions. It begins with joy and love, but once they are weakened, they also lose their most negative emotions, like anger or sadness. Eventually there will be the fateful day when indifference and apathy take over, when the emotionless townspeople reach a state known as the Coldness. Now that they have become mere automatons in the eyes of those around them, they are no more than soulless organic robots.

However, children and adolescents, all worried about their parents, still hold hope. Equipped with magic lanterns, they have chosen to leave the cities to capture feelings and emotions and bring them back to save the adults.

Kimochi no koryôshi is a “feel-good RPG” in the style of role playing games such as Ryuutama and Golden Sky Stories and mangas like Yotsuba-to, Azumanga Daioh and Mushishi. In this game, there is no fighting or violence. The goal for players is to take on the role of children whose emotions are still intact, and who will do everything in their power to capture feelings which manifest themselves as small firefly-like creatures, in order to heal the adults from the Coldness...

147911.name: Sneakers (1981)
147911.description:
User Summary

Use your spaceship to shoot down 8 waves of enemies. Make it thru all eight and start over again with increased difficulty.

147912.name: Space Eggs
147912.description:
User Summary

Break open the Space Eggs and shoot the aliens the hatch from them. Your ship upgrades as you lose them going from a small one-shot ship to bigger double barrel ships.

147913.name: Space Quarks
147913.description:
User Summary

Shoot the Space Quarks flying overhead in various formations. But, Watch out, They shoot back! Clear a wave and get another tank (life).

147914.name: Ceiling Zero
147914.description:
User Summary

An alien mother ship, protected by a force field, is dropping waves of ships. Shoot the ships that bounce around. Once the wave is destroyed, The force field moves down and the next wave is released. Their are 15 waves, Can you survive until the ceiling hits the floor?

147915.name: Mobscenity
boardgameversion: First Edition: Downloadable Creative Commons edition
147915.description:
Mobscenity is a card game where players take turns picking 2 seemingly innocent words from the deck to create a Mobscenity Phrase. Each player then tries to come up with the most obscene definition for the phrase. The game can be downloaded for printing under a Creative Commons license.

The oldest player starts in the role as the Master and take six cards from the deck. The Master chooses two cards from her/his hand and places them face up on the table. These two cards become the Mobscenity Roots. The Master then states what the Mobscenity Phrase will be by combining the two terms. For example, if the Master plays the cards “Wax” and “Dolphin,” the Master can state the Mobscenity Phrase is “Waxing the Dolphin.”

The other players are given 3 minutes to write both 1) a definition of the Obscenity Phrase and 2) a sentence that includes the Obscenity Phrase (the Master can decide to boot people from the round if they do not finish on time). When the time is up, each player folds up their written response and puts it in the hat. Players take turns reading the responses, and the Master decides which response s/he likes the best. The player with the best response gets 1 point.

147916.name: NBA 08: Featuring the Life Vol. 3
147916.description:
User Summary

NBA 08: Featuring the Life Vol. 3 is the third in the basketball franchise developed and published by Sony for PlayStation 2, PlayStation Portable, and PlayStation 3. The game offers all of the standard modes of play, such as exhibition, season, and playoff modes, as well as some mini-games such as 3-on-3 play. The Life mode (a PlayStation 2 exclusive feature) allows you to train and play alongside a struggling young team and their beloved coach, Coach T. The story in the Life mode is a direct continuation of the previous two games. In the PS3 version, however, the special feature is called "Game of the Week" and allows the player to download information on individual performances in the ongoing 2007-2008 season and to try to match those performances in the game.

147918.description:
BANG! Dodge City contains two decks of new BANG! cards, introducing new characters and new cards to shuffle together with the original deck. Moreover, it is possible to accommodate eight players: there are two Renegades in town!

The High Noon expansion is 13 cards: shuffle them and put the one called "High Noon" at the bottom. Each turn the Sheriff reveals a new High Noon card which every player must obey for the entire turn.
147918.name: BANG! Dodge City with High Noon expansion

147919.description:
GUISCARD is a medieval man-to-man skirmish game and is a reboot of the original Cry Havoc System. It is set during the epic conquest of Southern Italy and Sicily by the Normans, led by Robert Guiscard ("the cunning" or "the weasel"), in the eleventh century.
The game features over 170 unique characters belonging to the various factions of the time as the Byzantines, the Arabs of Sicily, the Lombards, the Germans and the Normans of course, who came as mere mercenaries in the middle of this mess of conflicting interests and who decided to seize power by arms.

GUISCARD is intended for those who want to play the Cry Havoc System but who can no longer get an original box.

Game contents:
> 6 full-color maps, giving a possibility of many different terrains;
> 3 sheets of overlays to provide more terrain variety and add buildings;
> 2 sheets of playing pieces printed in full color;
> 1 48-page rule booklet;
> 1 36-page booklet including the historical background, a guide to the playing pieces and 14 scenarios;
> 3 play sheets for handy reference;
> 1 10-sided die.

An optional counter tray can be purchased in the Shoppe of Cry Havoc Fan.

The game is available in 5 versions:
> English (Both booklets and play sheets in English)
> French (Both booklets and play sheets in French)
> Spanish (Both booklets in English, play sheets in Spanish)
> German (Both booklets in English, play sheets in German)
> Italian (Both booklets in English, play sheets in Italian)
147919.name: Guiscard

147920.description:
In Das Labyrinth des Pharao, players are graverobbers who want to go as deep inside a pyramid as they can, preferably discovering chambers that contain treasures along the way.

Each player starts the game with 28 identical tiles and a 5x5 grid representing a pyramid. Players each add the same tile to the grid each turn, slowly creating (if all goes well) a winding labyrinth inside the pyramid. When a player places a tile that shows one or more scarabs on it, he can choose to place a treasure marker on one or more scarabs. By the time that the third tile is placed, each player must decide which entrance to the pyramid his figure will take.

The game ends once the 5x5 grid is filled. Each player counts the length of the corridor that extends from his starting point, scoring one point for each space in this path. In addition, the player scores two points for each treasure that's surrounded by four walls as long as at least one of those walls abuts the corridor walked by the graverobber. Whoever has the highest score wins!

Das Labyrinth des Pharao includes rules for solo play as well as an advanced variant in which treasures are worth 1-3 points depending on their color, with this point value then multiplied by 1-4 depending on where its shared wall meets the corridor. The deeper the treasure along the path, the more points it's worth.
147920.name: Das Labyrinth des Pharao
boardgameexpansion: Das Labyrinth des Pharao: Sphinx und Triamide

147921.name: John Butterfield's Battle of the Bulge
147921.description:
John Butterfield's Battle of the Bulge is an analog version of the popular iOS game published by Shenandoah Studio. This printed version was made available as a Kickstarter incentive to supporters of Shenandoah's project.

Game covers the entire area of the conflict, and runs from December 16th through the 28th. Units are generally divisional in scale, with some brigade and regimental units. Map is divided into areas, regulating movement and combat. Multiple turns during each "day" are performed IGo-UGo, starting with the player having initiative for the day. A single area is activated, and the units within are given the option of moving. A player may also choose to "pass". Each "day" begins at 0600hrs, with an interesting mechanic of rolling for the amount of elapsed time for each turn, where a turn can be as short as zero minutes to as long as three hours. Each "day" ends when the time record for the day passes 1800hrs (or both players pass). Combat occurs at then end of any turn where units of opposing sides occupy the same area. Combat is done by rolling 10-sided dice for each strengthpoint of either infantry or armor in the combat, with simultaneous losses. Victory is gauged by the accumulation of points for enemy casualties, objective spaces, and Axis across the Meuse/exiting the western map edge, with daily sudden-death victory point levels.

Components consist of an 11' x 17" mounted map, 180 mounted counters/markers, a 12-page rule booklet, terrain effects chart, hours in the day and victory point charts, plastic bags for counter storage, and four ten-sided dice.

147922.name: Aquanemo
147922.description:
Aquanemo is a fast magnetic fishing game. There are many look-alike fishes on a deceptive mat whose design is made to handicap the fishermen.

The first player draws a card on which a fish is depicted and every one tries to find the right fish in the ocean. The fastest to find it gets to keep the card and return the fish to the water. Then a new card is drawn. The fisherman with the most cards at the end is the winner.

147926.name: Hound's Baying
147926.description:
From the front of the PDF:

A priestess of Sehanine Moonbow has gone missing in Neverwinter. Why was she taken, and what is she involved in? A Living Forgotten Realms adventure set in Neverwinter for characters of the Heroic tier (levels 1-10). This is the first adventure of the Devil's Play Major Quest, which continues with NEVE5-2 Serpent's Kiss and concludes in NEVE5-3 Spider's Web.

147927.name: Dragon (Issue 427 - Sep 2013)
rpgissuearticle: Eye on the Realms: The Sundering - To Rule Two Worlds
147927.description:
Contents:

3 Going Dark by Chris Perkins
Big changes are in the wind for Dragon and Dungeon. Read it here first.

4 The Lost World by Aeryn "Blackdirge" Rudel
We brush away the dust of ages and reveal primordial beasts that lived before the rise of dinosaurs, or after their extinction.
